> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Colin Green"
> <cgreen@d...> wrote:
> 
> > Had you thought about the best way to determine
> the layer? I guess 
> > you could calculate the shortest number of 'hops'
> for each hidden 
> > neuron to an input neuron? Trouble is you might
> end up with all of 
> > the neurons in layer 1 !!


Yeah...we've thought about placing nodes based on
shortest distance to either the input layer or output
layer.  We've also thought of simply evenly
distributing the nodes into a set number of hidden
layers (e.g. 10) to facilitate easier viewability.  We
have also considered a slightly more complicated
algorithm that would compute the nodes' distance from
both the input and output layers, and place it
accordingly.

The placement of nodes in layers is somewhat
arbitrary, since they really aren't in a layer.  My
inclination would be to favor placing them in layers
based on ease of readability when graphically
represented, since that's the primary reason for
putting them in layers in the first place.

--- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> This is basically how I did it in my network display
> routine.  (See
> for example the network picture at
> www.cs.utexas.edu/users/kstanley/neat.html) I
> typically don't find
> them all in one layer at all...it usually works out
> pretty well.  The
> one thing to make sure of is not to count a
> recurrent connection as a
> hop-  otherwise you can go in circles- but that
> requires also knowing
> which connections are recurrent, which may also be
> difficult depending
> how you keep track of things.  

Yep...good point.  We've got logic that determines
whether a connection is recurrent at the time we
generate the XML, so we add a boolean "recurrent" tag
to each connection as well.

> The problem is that
> this method is very
> computationally expensive, and also requires always
> knowing which
> connections are recurrent.  Once you get thousands
> of nodes I find it
> starts lagging out a lot before drawing anything.

Well, our XSL style sheet is going to be able to parse
a network of thousands of nodes (and therefore
probably tens or hundreds of thousands of
connections), but I'm not sure any such graphical
representation is going to be very human-readable, no
matter how it's laid out, at least if it draws every
single structure.

Derek
